title: Ramatoulaye Bah - CV
text:
Experience
DeWitt Wallace Library Library Access & Research Aide (Sept 2023 – Present)

Aided patrons with resource acquisition by processing materials, which included checking items out and checking them in when returned.
Improved user satisfaction through courteous and prompt customer service and by assisting patrons in finding materials, using computers, printing and answering inquiries.
Conducted research assistance for students, helping them navigate databases and online resources effectively (interlibrary loans, course reserves, etc).

826 MSP After-School Creative Lab Tutor - Volunteer (Oct 2023 - May 2024)
826 MSP empowers BIPOC K–12 students to think creatively, write effectively, and succeed academically.

Developed strong relationships with children through clear communication and active listening skills, fostering a positive learning environment.
Assisted children with reading, literacy activities, homework, and creative writing.

title: Ramatoulaye Bah - CV
text:
Leadership and Activities
Decolonise Club - Co-Leader

Discuss the impact of colonialism, socio-economic issues and the impact we can have on the school.
Led weekly group sessions on various social issues (e.g. white-savorism, fetishization in pop culture, privilege, neo- colonialism, critical race theory) and offered a discussion space for BIPOC students.
Organized educational and interactive workshops for school sponsors while contributing to the school’s DEIJ policy.

Mathematics, Statistics, Computer Science Student Advisory Board - Member

Planned career-related events and workshops such as Summer Opportunities Mentorship Panels, DS Portfolio Website using RStudio, and Introduction to LeetCode.
Organized and led monthly BIPOC in MSCS nights, overseeing logistics, promotion, food arrangements, and space setup.
Coordinated Student Feedback Sessions to close the gap between faculty and students and improve overall satisfaction.

Project Beauty - Co-Founder / Co-Leader
Youth social entrepreneurship project aimed at creating a more diverse, inclusive and sustainable fashion industry to deconstruct beauty standards.

Organized a photo shoot to promote underrepresented models and their stories.
Created a platform and an Instagram account with over 3000 views to increase our project’s visibility.
Partnered with local thrift stores to promote sustainable clothing.
Received a 300 euros award for the implementation and impact of the project.

title: Ramatoulaye Bah
text:
I am a rising Sophomore student at Macalester College. I plan on pursuing a Bachelor of Arts Degree in Computer Science and Linguistics with a minor in Spanish. Of French nationality and Guinean origin, I thrive to have a positive impact on my communities and I hope to use technology and the skills I foster daily as tools to achieve this goal. I’m passionate about tech, soccer, languages, social justice, and discovering new things every day! More about me


Macalester College | St. Paul MN  B.A. in Computer Science & Linguistics | Sept 2023 - May 2027

title: Hangman Game
text: Sad squirrel pic showing up when the user guesses the word wrong after six attempts in our game

title: Hangman Game
text:
My team for the final project holding the squirrel victory picture

Here are some key characteristics of the game:
Interactive Graphic User Interface (GUI): On a graphic screen, the game randomly selects a word that the user must guess. Each correct letter of the word pops up on the screen with every correct attempt throughout the game. If the guess is incorrect, an illustration of a hangman progressively appears with every wrong attempt until the game is over.
Illustrative Images: If a user successfully guesses the word, an image of a happy squirrel will appear on the screen. If a user does not successfully guess the correct word, an image of a sad squirrel will appear.
Descriptive labels: In the top part of the window, a representation of the hidden word with dashes indicates that its letters have not yet been guessed, and when guessed, it will update, revealing the letter and its position. Each dash represents a hidden letter of the word. At the bottom, a label with the number of attempts for each game is located. The label updates with every attempt, decreasing from 6 to 0.

title: Relevant Courses
text: This coding bootcamp is to learn the basics of HTML, CSS & JavaScript. Through building a Webpage participants delve into styling with CSS, HTML 5 & The Semantic Web, Responsive Design and JavaScript basics. On completion of this coding course, a certificate of completion will be received.

title: Relevant Courses
text:
COMP 127 - Object-Oriented Programming and Abstraction
This course is an introduction to the building blocks of software design: abstraction, decomposition, and encapsulation. Using object-oriented programming in Java, we create graphics, games, and simulations, and explore natural language processing. Topics include: classes, objects, polymorphism, inheritance, testing, refactoring, events, closures, streams, immutability, parallel programming, and version control. The course culminates in a student-designed project. There is a required 1.5 hour laboratory section associated with this course.

title: Relevant Courses
section: COMP 123 - Core Concepts in Computer Science
text:
COMP 123 - Core Concepts in Computer Science
This course introduces the field of computer science, including central concepts such as the design and implementation of algorithms and programs, testing and analyzing programs, the representation of information within the computer, and the role of abstraction and metaphor in computer science. The exploration of these central ideas will draw examples from a range of application areas including multimedia processing, turtle graphics, and text processing. Course work uses the Python programming language.

title: Relevant Courses
text:
CS50x - Introduction to Computer Science
CS50x is Harvard University’s introduction to the intellectual enterprises of computer science and the art of programming for majors and non-majors alike, with or without prior programming experience. An entry-level course taught by David J. Malan, CS50x teaches students how to think algorithmically and solve problems efficiently. Topics include abstraction, algorithms, data structures, encapsulation, resource management, security, software engineering, and web development. Languages include C, Python, SQL, and JavaScript plus CSS and HTML. Problem sets inspired by real-world domains of biology, cryptography, finance, forensics, and gaming.
Students who earn a satisfactory score on 9 problem sets (i.e., programming assignments) and a final project are eligible for a certificate in this self-paced course.
Outcomes of this course:

A broad and robust understanding of computer science and programming
How to think algorithmically and solve programming problems efficiently
Concepts like abstraction, algorithms, data structures, encapsulation, resource management, security, software engineering, and web development
Familiarity with a number of languages, including C, Python, SQL, and JavaScript plus CSS and HTML
How to engage with a vibrant community of like-minded learners from all levels of experience
How to develop and present a final programming project to your peers
Harvard University certificate upon completion

title: About Me
text:
Working as a Library Front Desk Aide at my college’s library, DeWitt Wallace Library, has been my first professional experience. I’m grateful for the chance I have to be in such a fun and supportive community where I get to learn new valuable skills such as customer service, independence and team-work.
Alongside that, I volunteer every week at 826 MSP as an After-School Creative Lab tutor. This experience with K-12 BIPOC children allows me to foster an engaging learning environment using active listening and collective responsibility. Community engagement has always been important to me ever seen I grew up amidst the creation of my mother’s association, SMEG (Solidarity to the Mothers and Children of Guinea), which helps those back in our country of origin. I helped with selling African goods in flea markets for fundraising, distributing flyers to promote donations, and sorting through donated items such as clothes, children’s books, and non-perishable food to be prepared for shipping.
My numerous responsibility roles babysitting my nieces, contributing to local food banks and associations stem from my goal to be an actor in society. In my future career, I want to combine this mission with technology and potentially linguistics to meet the needs of the people. I am open to any internship in software engineering/web development/startup opportunities. If you think I’m a good fit, please contact me via Ramatoulaye.bah2805@gmail.com

title: About Me
section: My Journey from Paris to Minnesota
text: My Journey from Paris to Minnesota

title: About Me
text:
I was born and grew up in France in the suburbs of Paris where I was raised in a Guinean household with four siblings. Coming from an underprivileged neighborhood with non-graduate parents, it became my ambition to combat social inequalities by developing my passion for education and technology and realizing the impact I can have on the world.
In 10th grade, during my time at the French public high school Lycée Polyvalent Eugène Ionesco, I was introduced to United World Colleges (UWC), and after a long selection process, I left for UWC Maastricht, an international high school in the Netherlands that shapes future dreamers and changemakers ready to have an impact on the world of tomorrow. The full scholarship of €58,000 offered me the opportunity to access a unique education, the International Baccalaureate, surrounded by people from over a hundred different nationalities. This two-year experience encouraged me to take multiple initiatives: I contributed to campus life with Spirit Team; discussed the impacts of colonialism by leading the Decolonise Club; offered a learning environment to students through the Coding Club; created an entrepreneurial project to deconstruct beauty standards with Project Beauty, and much more. I am constantly learning from others and am fortunate to develop my passions while exploring new ones. I am grateful to have been able to take these initiatives while focusing on my studies and fully enjoying my UWC experience.
Thanks to these experiences, I was accepted into a recognized liberal arts college in the US, Macalester College, where I have the opportunity to continue exploring my passions and developing my skills on a daily basis. Pursuing a degree in Computer Science at Macalester College to become a software engineer will give me the opportunity to have a positive impact and to be able, later on, to give the same opportunities to young people from a similar background, following the support I received throughout my life.

title: About Me
text:
Quick Facts About Me

I love football (soccer)! I’ve been playing for over 9 years now with various teams including men’s teams, D3 teams, Dutch teams, adult teams, varsity teams or even futsal teams.

title: About Me
text:
I started programming in middle school with Scratch to familiarize myself with problem solving and pseudocode and later on in high school, I took advantage of the free online resources available to me to further my learning (Codeacademy, Harvard CS50x, Coursera, freeCodeCamp, YouTube etc).
Outside of football, I read a lot of books (love the fictional ones!), lift, romanticize life, cook, bake and play video games. One thing I would love to try though is knitting!
I speak four languages; French, Jakhanke (ethnic language), English, Spanish; and I’m currently learning Indonesian and Arabic.
I’m 18 years old. Born in October, 2005 in France. I now live in St. Paul Minnesota.



Thank you for taking the time to read!
